captions.text: (Music)

Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking
Snow Globe Cake

Hi Bold Bakers! Today I am making a really
special Snow Globe Cake. I will show you how

easy it is to make this beautiful, impressive
cake. Also, today is another episode of my

Chocolicious series over on the Kin Community
Channel, where I show you how to make Homemade

Chocolate Truffles for the holidays. So make
sure you stick around to check that out.
So let's get baking!

So the base of our Snow Globe is a Coconut
Cake. Today we are making a white cake which

I've never shown you before so this is a new
one to add to your repertoire. And I want

to say a big thank you to Sarah who sent me
a message on Facebook and told me about Snow

Globe Cakes because I had never heard of them
before and I think it's such a great idea
especially for Christmas.

We are going to start out by measuring our
wet and dry ingredients separately.

In a large jug, we are going to measure our milk and
our egg whites. And then we're going to whisk

them together. In a separate bowl, add in
your flour, baking powder and salt
and then mix these together.

Our next step is to cream together our butter
and our sugar. You can do this on a stand

mixer or with a hand mixer. Cream the butter
a little bit on its own first to loosen it

up and then add in the sugar. When your butter
and sugar are well creamed, we're going to

add in the rest of our ingredients. I like
to add vanilla extract to my Coconut Cake

because it gives it a really nice flavor.
To this we're going to add half of our flour

mix and half of our egg mix. Then turn back
on the machine and mix these two gently together.

It might seem like kind of an odd process
but if you add flour in at once or the milk

in at once, your mix will curdle and it won't
be good.

And then when that's just combined, add in
the rest. At this stage you only want to gently

mix these to form a smooth batter. And there
you have it, a beautiful cake mix that didn't

curdle. This is what it should look like.
Oh man, I love cake mix.

Scrape around the sides of the bowl in case
there are any lumps lurking around. Now we're

going to grease and line our cake tin. Now
if you remember my little trick, save your

butter wrapper and that's what we're going
to use to grease our tin with. And then just
line it with a round piece of parchment.

For this cake, I'm using a 6 inch cake tin
but you can use an 8 or a 9.
I just like it small and high.
Then just pour in your lovely batter.

Bake your cake at 350 degrees F for around
an hour/hour and ten minutes until it's firm
on top and a beautiful golden brown.

While your cake is baking, it's a really good
time to make your frosting. I'm using my cream

cheese frosting recipe from my Red Velvet
Cheesecake video. So make sure you go check

that out to see how to make it. For my Coconut
Cake, I like to add a little bit of raspberry

jam between the layers. You can use a different
jam or you can just leave it out.

I really hope you guys have been liking the
edible gifts videos that I've been doing. I

release another one today to show you how
to make a variety of Chocolate truffles over

on the Kin Community Channel as part of my
Chocolicious series so make sure you go over

and check that out once this video is over.
And if you haven't already done so, don't
forget to subscribe to my channel.

Our timer has gone off so let's check on our
cake. And here's our cake, it looks so good.

It's firm on top and a beautiful golden brown.
It smells yummy. We're going to leave it in

the tin, let it go a little bit cold, then
turn it out onto a wire rack and let it go
completely cold.

When your cake is done, it's time to start
icing it. I made this cake the day before

because it will be much easier to cut and
to frost.

When it comes to cakes, I'm all about the
filling so I'm going to put two layers in
this cake so you get more filling.

Ok, let's check out the inside of our cake
and see how well it turned out. Look at that.

It's perfect. All those fine little crumbs.
Beautiful.

You might notice that your cake is a little
bit round on top. We want to even that out

so just get your knife and slice straight
across it. We do this because when you frost

it, it gives it a much nicer, clean finish.
Do not discard the leftover cake. It's a little
gift for the person who made it. Mmm.

Now that we've cut the layers in our cake,
we're going to flip it over because this bottom

is now going to become the top so that when
you frost it you've got a beautiful, clean finish.

Now we're going to spread jam and cream cheese
frosting throughout the layers. Spread a generous

layer of jam and cream cheese frosting all
around the cake. I just love the taste of

these flavors together. Then put your cake
layer on top and continue adding more frosting

and jam. And then on with the top of the cake.
Before we start frosting the rest of the cake,

I like to take a pastry brush and brush away
any loose crumbs around the cake so they don't
get into your icing.

So now we're going to do our crumb layer.
Now I've shown you this technique before in

the Red Velvet Cheesecake video and the purpose
of it is to gather any loose crumbs around

the cake so when you put on your final layer
of frosting you don't see any crumbs and it

has a beautiful finish. As you can see this
is a really thin layer of frosting and it

looks pretty rough right now but we're going
to pop it in the fridge and when we go to
frost on top of this it's going to look beautiful.

Our cake has been in the fridge for around
15 minutes and our crumb layer is nice and

stiff so we can go ahead and put the other
layer of frosting on top of this. The best

way to frost a cake, I find, is to do it fast.
Don't think too much about it and just go

for it and you'll always get the best results.
You don't have to be too finicky about the

icing because we're actually going to cover
this whole thing in coconut so you won't see

any little mistakes. Once you've frosted your whole
cake, we're going to add on the coconut which

will eventually be the snow for your snow
globe. Add a generous amount of coconut on

the top and the sides of your cake. And don't
be afraid about making a mess. With your hands,

stick it to the side of the cake. You guys
know I'm all about easy ways to decorate cakes

and it doesn't get much easier than adding
coconut all over the top. It looks beautiful

and it doesn't matter what the frosting looks
like underneath. I'm going to pop this into

the fridge and go ahead and get the rest of
the decorations ready to finish off this beautiful
Snow Globe Cake.

So how am I going to turn this cake into a
snow globe? Very simply, with some Christmas

decorations and a glass ball. This ball can
be found in most hardware stores and florists.

Now just add your decorations to the top of
the cake. You can use any of your holiday

favorites. Then just place your glass bowl
on top. It's that easy!

This Snow Globe Cake looks beautiful but I
want to finish it off with a little bit of

snow on top to make it look really magical.
I like to add a bow for a splash of color.

This cake would make a great addition to any
table on Christmas Day. It almost looks too
good to eat but I'm going to eat it anyways.

Make sure you head over to the Kin Community
Channel where I show you how to make Homemade

Chocolate Truffles from scratch. Thank you
so much for watching. And don't forget to

subscribe to my channel. I'll see you back
here again next Thursday for more Bigger Bolder Baking.

title: Snow Globe Cake - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep. 46
